OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and manage a patient presenting with sudden, unilateral loss of vision.

Patient_Actor.History: Patient reports sudden, painless loss of vision in her right eye that occurred about 30 minutes ago. She mentions the episode happened while she was watching TV. On further questioning, she reports a history of coronary artery disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She admits to not always adhering to her prescribed medication regimen.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Sudden, painless loss of vision in the right eye
Secondary_Symptoms: No changes in vision in the left eye
No recent history of eye trauma

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Coronary artery disease, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus.
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Patient lives alone and is recently retired. She smokes 10 cigarettes a day and drinks alcohol occasionally.
Patient_Actor.Review_of_Systems: Denies recent headache, dizziness, chest pain, or difficulty breathing.

Fundoscopy.Right_Eye: Pale, white retina with a bright red area within the macula. Normal optic disc.

OSCE_Examination.Objective_for_Doctor: Assess and diagnose the patient presenting with sudden loss of vision in one eye.

Patient_Actor.History: The patient was brought to the emergency department because of sudden, painless loss of vision in her right eye that occurred 30 minutes ago while watching TV. She has a history of coronary artery disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus but has had trouble adhering to her medication regimen.

Symptoms.Primary_Symptom: Sudden, painless loss of vision in the right eye

Patient_Actor.Past_Medical_History: Coronary artery disease, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus
Patient_Actor.Social_History: Has difficulty adhering to medication regimen

Fundoscopic_Examination.Right_Eye: Pale, white retina with a bright red area within the macula. The optic disc appears normal.
